SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Harry Lorne Martyn
2. Your address: 1301 16th Shaunavon Sask.
3. Date: June 9th 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Bowmanville Ont., Durham County, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Brown Martyn Storekeeper, Grocer, Hardware, Butchery Shop, Tinsmith shop, Flour & Seed, and Seeds of all kinds which he bought & sold wholesale & retail
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1913
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Ontario 1884 till 1913

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 25 yrs.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Adventure & have a look at the west

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Through other people. Reading about it and listening to my father tell about what a country it was going to be & what chances he was always telling us we were all going west someday & we would all get free land. 4 Boys & 3 girls, Father & Mother and we would form our own Community & He would run a general store. Mother was to be cook. We children were of that time grown up fast 3 girls old enough to take up land & one boy & we 3 older coming along about 1 year behind him & 2 years apart. But it never happened. Father kept right on in his business & we boys all had start work experience all kinds. So when I was 25 yrs old the West go west young man & I went got one & 2 came west, on a harvest excursion in 1909

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? I was on a wild goose chase and I forgot it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use? Box car, Settler effects, 4 horses, 1 cow, 2 dogs, farm machinery, house hold goods, 1 farm hand + my self. We slept in an ear + took 10 days from Bowmanville Ont to Gull Lake, from there to South Bay + 6 P.M. From there to Gull Lake Sask. Had a grand trip + met a lot of fine people who were coming west on the west.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). I met two brothers (W Prossy & John Prossy) + we were friends till they both passed on (Illness) They settled at what is now Cluney Sask. I settled at what is now Shaunavon Sask. and still here in 1952.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Gull Lake first night + at a farmer's the next night and I had my dinner with the Surveyors who were camped on the prairie right near the town of Shaunavon + more built up as 4 miles south on W S E of 30 - 7 - 18 W 3rd.

Working for my Father in a general store, looking after the meat counter and clerking in other departments.

    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    We traveled little. We did visit our friends, say once

    traveled by airplane for a thrill.

Weary appeal.

We came here to make a home for ourselves and we did and we are still here but not on the farm. We have rented on the 1/3 share basis and live in town since 1950. Pick up odd jobs. I do a little dealing by self anything I can make a dollar on make

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving? Not that I know of.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? Yes.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been a School Trustee for years & have been Chairman of the School Board (Power School district) and was on the Telephone Co. as President and on the directory or board for years from 1919 till 1951 and was very glad to get my pay for. I could tell you all about it but not had much to do with it.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My wife who was born in 1909 from a mountain was one of the first women to settle in the district in 1909 (June 15th) and can still spin some fine stories also her brother Fritz T.H. Power who is 81 yrs old. Come and see them here in Shaunavon.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Power & the lignite coal mines which are close to his farm. It was one of the first to dig coal in this district for his own use.
